instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H? PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H is the input voltage to the PP3V42_G3H buck converter circuit, it can be either charger voltage or battery voltage depending on what the system power source is. This often shorts to ground when one of the input capacitors dies. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.ADAPTER_EN: What is ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..

threads.title: No boot <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi, 
the customer say before intermittent start, but now no boot, green led and pass to orange without battery.
i check this voltage
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 16,84V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> = 16,33V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_R</SIGNAL> = 12,57V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> = 3,427V
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 3,387V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> = 3,415V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> =3,414V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3,335V
no liquid, the board is clean, what can i do?
thanks

threads.title: No boot <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: No fan spin or any S3 rails? Check for pulses on S3 rails, inspect closer for liquid damage. PPVRTC present?

threads.title: No boot <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
No fan spin but not turn in start on this model (or just 2015?)
Sorry but what do you think about S3 rails? and check pulses on S3 rails, i don't understand where, i don't find on the schematic.
can you explain me for the S3 rails please?
I inspect all the board, i don't see liquid, the board is very clean.
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3,3332V

threads.title: No boot <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
S3 as in the power state like S0, S3, S5. On the newer boards like this they mostly call it S4 now. So check for power pulses on <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> rail. If the board is power cycling there will be very short pulses which are hard to catch on a multimeter. If you have an auto range meter it will never see them. Preferably use a scope to catch the pulses.

Few more things you can check is SMC_ <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>. Check all rails for short to GND. Inspect the usual suspects for corrosion: <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and the termination resistors in the data lines to <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>.

threads.title: No boot <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I don't see anything on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>, just 5V no short pulse with my scope. it's another signal?
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> = 3,34V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>= 3,34V
i check all rail no short, good voltage, no corrosion, very clean board. The CPU is warm, is it the CPU?

threads.title: No boot <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: CPU cannot be warm is it does not power on. The only way the CPU can get warm is a shorted FET. Some voltage must get to the CPU somehow. PPVRTC present? <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> getting warm too?

threads.title: No boot <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
No it's really the <CHIP>U0500</CHIP> who warm at 70°c when i plug the power cable. I check with thermal camera, when i remove the cable the cpu temperature fall.
what do you talk about FET? example please? 
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3,3332V
No <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> is not warm, only warm because CPU is on the other side.
thanks

threads.title: No boot <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Measure resistance from F7140 to L7310.....

threads.title: No boot <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: No need to measure anything really. CPU will be dead anyway, the end.

threads.title: No boot <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
No boot <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Sure you can but it is a waste of time...

threads.title: No boot <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Sorry but i try to understand, why is it a waste of time? do you think if i change the CPU, the board don't work? or it's more difficult than the GPU? or anything else?
thanks

threads.title: No boot <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Go and see how much a CPU would cost first......
Then there is the ME region BIOS issue. Also need to fix what killed the CPU. Then you have to pray it works and there is not more damage. As I said, a waste of time.

threads.title: No boot <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 24580"]Go and see how much a CPU would cost first......
Then there is the ME region BIOS issue. Also need to fix what killed the CPU. Then you have to pray it works and there is not more damage. As I said, a waste of time.[/QUOTE]

Hell, try reflow/ reball one and watch the CPU warp super bad, Havent figured a way round that yet myself.
